title: Introduction
content:
Wolstenholme's theorem (1862) states that for prime p >= 5:

C(2p-1, p-1) = 1 (mod p^3)

This strengthens Babbage's 1819 result (mod p^2). The theorem connects binomial coefficients to harmonic numbers.

title: Central Binomial Coefficient
content:
The key quantity:

centralBinomial(p) = C(2p-1, p-1)

For example:
- p = 5: C(9, 4) = 126
- p = 7: C(13, 6) = 1716
- p = 11: C(21, 10) = 352716

title: Babbage's Theorem
content:
**Babbage (1819)**: For p >= 3, C(2p-1, p-1) = 1 (mod p^2).

This is one power of p weaker than Wolstenholme.

Verified for p = 3, 5, 7:
- p = 3: 10 = 1 (mod 9)
- p = 5: 126 = 1 (mod 25)
- p = 7: 1716 = 1 (mod 49)

title: Why p >= 5
content:
**p = 3 fails Wolstenholme**: C(5, 2) = 10, and 10 mod 27 = 10 != 1.

(But p = 3 satisfies Babbage: 10 mod 9 = 1.)

**p = 2 fails both**: C(3, 1) = 3, and 3 mod 8 = 3 != 1.

The bound p >= 5 is sharp.

title: Wolstenholme Primes
content:
A prime p is a **Wolstenholme prime** if:

C(2p-1, p-1) = 1 (mod p^4)

This is one power stronger than the theorem guarantees.

Only two are known: 16843 and 2124679.

We prove 5 and 7 are NOT Wolstenholme primes.
mathContext: IsWolstenholmePrime p := Prime p AND centralBinomial p % p^4 = 1

title: Harmonic Connection
content:
Wolstenholme's theorem is equivalent to:

The numerator of H_{p-1} = 1 + 1/2 + ... + 1/(p-1) is divisible by p^2 for p >= 5.

This connects binomial coefficients to harmonic sums in a deep way.
